content.description: Climb face up not using the vertical cracks.
content.location: It is on the face between the thin crack (Flutterby) and the diagonal feature (Hidden Magic).

content.description: Climb face to the top, not using the vertical cracks.
content.location: The face between the two rightmost vertical cracks.

content.description: Climb a face just left of the big crack not using the crack.
content.location: It is on the left side of the cliff just left of the first vertical crack.

content.description: Climb a face to the top not using the cracks on the left and right.
content.location: This ascends the face between the second and third crack from the left.

content.description: Ascend the slabby face on the left-facing side of the toproping wall on knobby holds. The crack is off route. This can be done as a highball boulder, but toproping would be easy from the trees above. This face doesn't get climbed much due to being out of view and having longer, more popular toproping routes nearby.
content.protection: The trees up top are perfect for toproping. Bring long slings.
content.location: From the lot near the traffic light on Hammond Pond Parkway, walk a short distance on the dirt road until you see the main toproping wall. From the base of the wall, walk around the left side to a smaller, left-facing wall. Practice Face is the slab to the left of the crack.

content.description: Follow a thin crack to the top.
content.protection: A standard rack or a toprope.
content.location: This is the thin crack between the two wider cracks in the middle of the cliff, Milk Run and Free and Easy.

content.description: Follow a big crack to the top.
content.protection: A standard rack or a toprope.
content.location: It ascends the first big crack from the left.

content.description: Do a long traverse along the horizontal crack over the whole cliff, from the left or from the right.
content.protection: You can put gear along the horizontal crack, but you may not need any. You won't fall very far and probably hit ground before the gear catches you.
content.location: Start on the far left (or far right).

content.description: This is a 35' crack that widens at the top. It is good for a quick, trad fix or top roping.
content.protection:
Leading: a standard rack.

 Toproping: 2 x 20' slings and lockers. Anchor off to the two trees above.
content.location: In the center the lower wall, this is that vertical crack that widens at the top.

content.description:
The route has two variations, according to Boston Rocks guide. One ascends diagonally and one goes straight up vertically. 

  About half way up the wall, you cross a giant horizontal crack which makes a pleasant resting spot. Other than that, there are plenty of holds for feet and hands, but they tend to be small and a little slippery, due to the nature of the puddingstone at Hammond.
content.protection: There are two trees at the top which can be used for anchors. They are about 15 feet back.
content.location:
If you stand facing Lower Wall, there's one giant vertical crack down the middle (it's called Free and Easy). To the right of this crack, there's a protruding feature which runs diagonally up, and to the right. This feature starts at the ground and runs up towards the top of Cracker Jack, to the right. 

  Hidden Magic follows this diagonal feature. 

  A variation has you starting midway between the start and end of this diagonal feature, and climbing straight up, rather than following the diagonal.

content.description: Climb a face on the left side to the top.
content.protection: This route can be lead by placing small cams or tricams in the horizontals, but beginning leaders may want to avoid this route due to a substantial run out before the first placement.
content.location: It is the [second] route on the left side.

content.description: This is a nice easy trad route. Typical pudding stone found at Hammond Pond. The crack is inconsistent so cam placement can be tricky.
content.protection: A standard rack up to a #2 with small and medium nuts. For a toprope, bring a couple of long slings or webbing to anchor off the trees.
content.location: On the left end of the wall, this is the second crack (as you face the wall) to the left of Milk Run.

content.description: Follow wide crack to the top.
content.protection: A standard rack or a toprope.
content.location: This is the right one of the two wide crack in the middle of the face.

content.description: Follow a very thin crack that thins out halfway up.
content.location: This ascends a thin, vertical crack just right of the two big, wide cracks in the middle of the cliff.

climbs.name: Cracker Jack
climbs.fa: probably someone in rope soled shoes

content.description: This is a fine crack line (that starts a few feet off the ground) on the right side of the Lower Wall.  I recall learning basics about crack technique, learning to lead, learning to solo on this same crack.  It's so fun.  It got 3 out of 3 stars in the old Boston Rocks.  After all these years, it still brings back fond memories.  Here is a nice shot from the MIT photo contest for your viewing pleasure.
content.location: This is on the right side of the Lower Walls.

content.description: This is a good easy crack climb on the far right side of the Lower Walls.
content.protection: Good trad gear the whole way up: cams to 0.75, standard rack of nuts. TR on a double-trunk oak at the top.
content.location: It is the continuous splitter finger crack on the far right side of the Lower Walls about 10 feet right of Cracker Jack. You can't miss it!

content.description:
This is one of the more popular walls here. It is probably all of only 35 ft or less, but it is great fun for the beginner climber. Many a climber has cut his or her climbing teeth here. It faces east. Some of these climbs can be led. For history buffs, there is an ancient bolt here. Who placed it and when? Long slings are necessary for top rope anchors here. Be careful at the edge with wet leaves around. Nice photo, top row, 2nd photo

 L->R:

Left Wall A. Practice Face, 3 or V-easy, 1p, 15', TR or boulder. B. Happy Slabs, 4, 1p TR. C. Shortcake, 8, 1p, TR. D. Old Tree, 2, 1p, TR or gear. E. Half and Half, 4, 1p, 35', TR or gear. F. Pudding Face, 6 or 7, 1p, TR. G. Milk Run, 3, 1p, 35', gear. H. Pipe Cleaner, 5, 1p, TR or gear. I. Free and Easy, 4, 1p, TR or gear. J. Flutterby, 6, 1p, TR. K. Your Lead, 7, 1p, TR. L. Hidden Magic, 7, 30', TR. M. Cracker Jack, 6, 1p, 35', gear. N. Toy Surprise, 6, 1p, TR. O. The Cleft, 4, 1p, 30', gear.

No Reverse Traverse, 7, gear.

Middle Wall A. unknown, 3 B. unknown, 4 C. unknown, 3 D. unknown, 2 E. unknown, 3 F. unknown, 2

Right Wall A. unknown,2 B. unknown, 4 C. unknown, 1 D. unknown, 4 E. unknown, 4
